bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: A central figure in Ulster's literary culture since the late 1960's, Frank Ormsby has led a lively and multifarious writing life as a poet, book and magazine editor, and teacher based in Belfast. Born in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland in 1947, Ormsby studied English at Queen's University Belfast, where he received an MA. In 1971, he began teaching at the Royal Belfast Academical Institution, and he has been Head of English there for many years.

As a poet, Ormsby established himself in the early seventies with two chapbooks, Ripe for Company (1971) and Business as Usual (1973). During the 1971-1972 academic year, Ormsby also participated in the Belfast Group meetings organized by Seamus Heaney and Michael Allen. He won the Eric Gregory Award in 1974, and his 1977 volume of poems, A Store of Candles, was a Poetry Book Society Choice. Ormsby's other collections of poems, A Northern Spring (1986) and The Ghost Train (1995) have been published with the Gallery Press. In 1992, Ormsby won a Cultural Traditions Award given in memory of John Hewitt, and in 2002 he was honored with the Lawrence O'Shaughnessy Award for Poetry from the University of St Thomas at St Paul, Minnesota.

Ormsby began his editorial career in 1969, when he and Michael Foley succeeded James Simmons as co-editors of The Honest Ulsterman. From 1972 to 1984, Ormsby was the sole editor of this small but important literary magazine that offered both younger and established Northern Irish writers invaluable access to a wider public. After editing The Honest Ulsterman with Robert Johnstone from 1984 until 1989, Ormsby left to dedicate himself both to his own poetry and various other editorial projects.

Ormsby's other editorial projects including several very important anthologies produced since the late 1970's. Poets From Northern Ireland was first published in 1979 and then revised in 1990. Similarly, The Long Embrace: Twentieth Century Irish Love Poems was published in 1987 and also reprinted in 1990. In 1987, Ormsby produced Northern Windows: An Anthology of Ulster Autobiography. Another anthology of mostly prose, Thine in Storm and Calm: An Amanda McKittrick Ros Reader, was released in 1988. Published in 1991, The Collected Poems of John Hewitt is a definitive and extensively annotated collection of this major Belfast poet's work. Ormsby's A Rage for Order: Poetry of the Northern Ireland Troubles (1992) is a much heralded and widely used anthology of "Troubles poetry." His most recent anthology is The Hip Flask: Short Poems from Ireland (2001). In addition to these individual volumes, he edited the Poetry Ireland Review (Numbers 53-56).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Frank Ormsby papers consist of the poet-editor's personal and literary papers from 1968 to 2004. These papers catalog Ormsby's literary career as a poet, an anthologist, and a long-term editor of The Honest Ulsterman. The collection focuses on two interconnected areas of Ormsby's literary life. On one hand, the papers highlight Ormsby's output as a poet, a writer about poetry, and an editor-anthologist. On the other hand, this collection is notable for its materials relating to The Honest Ulsterman and Ormsby's role as editor of this magazine, which played an important role in the late twentieth century literary culture of Northern Ireland.

Ormsby's poetry has been consistently well-received and widely acknowledged since the early 1970's. An extensive series of manuscript and typescript drafts of published and unpublished poems charts the development of the poet across time. Like many other poets in Ireland and Great Britain, Ormsby has also enjoyed a parallel career as a literary journalist. He has written many reviews and essays about other writers and collections of poetry.

Apart from his writing poetry and critical prose and his magazine editing, Ormsby, as anthologist and literary editor, has produced seven anthologies or other edited volumes. Materials relating to the publication of these volumes are arranged in a distinct subseries of writing by Ormsby. Such materials include: bibliographical and biographical research materials, permissions, contents lists and indexes, drafts of introductions, and copies of primary documents. Correspondence with contributors, editors, or publishers is kept separately in the subseries for personal literary correspondence. Similarly, reviews and other printed matter relating to these texts are found in the subseries for printed material about Ormsby.

His editorial work on these volumes as well as with The Honest Ulsterman has ensured a wide and varied correspondence with many important writers in Ireland and Great Britain. Though Ormsby's personal literary correspondence and his editorial correspondence relating to The Honest Ulsterman are located in two distinct series, individual letters frequently mention both the poet's own work and The Honest Ulsterman. Information related to the poet and to the magazine may be found throughout the collection. In this collection's several correspondence subseries, writers of interest include Ciaran Carson, Peter Fallon, Seamus Heaney, John Hewitt, Kathleen Jamie, Edna and Michael Longley, Derek Mahon, Medbh McGuckian, Paul Muldoon, Tom Paulin, Carol Rumens, and James Simmons, among many others.

Because of the magazine's importance, both for Ormsby and Northern Irish literary culture, The Honest Ulsterman materials constitute a separate and sizeable series, which includes correspondence, author files, manuscript submissions, publications, and printed material regarding The Honest Ulsterman. Manuscript and typescript drafts of poetry and prose sent to Ormsby are divided according to those submitted for magazine publication and those shared with the poet on a more personal basis. Because friends sent material both for personal reasons and for publication, the series of writings by others is relatively small compared to The Honest Ulsterman author files and magazine submissions subseries. Anything sent with an eye towards publication has been kept in The Honest Ulsterman series. Similarly, printed material regarding the magazine is arranged separately from other printed material relating to Ormsby and his work as poet and anthologist.

Other important materials include worksheets by Norman Dugdale, Seamus Heaney, Michael Longley, Paul Muldoon, Bernard MacLaverty, and James Simmons from meetings of the Belfast Group in 1971-1972. Photographs of many of the personages whose work is represented in this collection are arranged in a separate series.
Unprocessed additions include writings by Ormsby, writings by others including Michael Longley and James Simmons, correspondence, and printed material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: (1) Correspondence, (2) The Honest Ulsterman literary materials, (3) Writings by Ormsby, (4) Writing by others, (5) Printed material by and about Ormsby, (6) Photographs, (7) Personal materials, and (8) Unprocessed additions.

separatedmaterial.head: Related Materials in This Repository
separatedmaterial.p: Seamus Heaney collection, Michael Longley papers, Derek Mahon papers, Medbh McGuckian papers, Tom Paulin papers, Peter Fallon/Gallery Press papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series is comprised of two subseries, one for personal literary correspondence and the other for project and business correspondence. Personal literary correspondence refers to letters for the most part sent to Ormsby regarding his own literary career as a poet or educator. The project and business correspondence subseries contains communications of a contractual and/or editorial nature sent to Ormsby by the editors or publishing houses that produced his volumes of poetry and other books.

One of the curious features of the correspondence in the Frank Ormsby papers is that it is both personal and editorial. Often in the same letter, a correspondent will address Ormsby as editor of The Honest Ulsterman and then comment on Ormsby's own poetry or editorial projects. Even as correspondence related to Ormsby's careers as poet and magazine editor is often interrelated, an effort has been made to distinguish and arrange separately letters pertaining to each of these roles. Correspondence relating to The Honest Ulsterman will be found in two places in Series 2. Some letters are located in author files and others are in a correspondence subseries. Notable writers in this series include: Peter Fallon, Seamus Heaney, John Hewitt, Edna and Michael Longley, Tom Paulin, and James Simmons.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: (1.1) Personal literary correspondence and (1.2) Project and business correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The personal literary correspondence showcases Frank Ormsby's wide-ranging literary interests and activities. Much of this correspondence is of both a personal and a professional nature. Of special interest is correspondence with various newspaper, magazine, and journal editors about the publication of Ormsby's own poetry and prose. This subseries also contains correspondence with various colleagues and academics about poetry or history as well as Ormsby's own activities and travel plans. The final folder contains drafts of letters that Ormsby has sent to others. Personal correspondence with Seamus Heaney, which is restricted, is located at the end of this correspondence series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronologic order, with undated correspondence is filed at the end of the subseries.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Subseries 1.1, letters by Seamus Heaney are closed to researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Ormsby's correspondence of an editorial and/or business nature. The subseries is divided into two subsections. The project correspondence subsection attempts to maintain the integrity of Ormsby's own files arranged according to specific book projects that he edited. Most of the correspondence in these folders pertains to project research, permissions, and contributors' correspondence. Specific contractual or financial correspondence related to the various book projects is included with the correspondence organized according to publisher.

The business correspondence subsection is arranged according to specific publishing houses. Individual items are then arranged chronologically. In some cases, as in the Gallery Press or Oxford University Press correspondence, extensive editorial exchanges between the publisher and Ormsby (as poet) are segregated from the contractual and fiduciary correspondence. In other instances, as in the Blackstaff Press correspondence, contractual and editorial correspondence is thoroughly mixed together. In many cases, editors simultaneously refer to or attach together both editorial comments and contractual materials related to the books Ormsby edited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The volume and significance of the Ormsby collection's papers related to The Honest Ulsterman necessitate the organization of this material in a distinct series. This series contains documents pertaining to all aspects of the magazine's production.

As mentioned, the correspondence received by Ormsby from readers and contributors to The Honest Ulsterman is distinguished from Ormsby's other personal literary and business correspondence. It is important to note that many of the letters referring to The Honest Ulsterman in the present series also mention Ormsby's personal or individual poetic life. An effort has been made to distinguish between letters that focus principally on the personal or poetic life and those chiefly addressed to Ormsby's role as a magazine editor. But, if researching The Honest Ulsterman, it is advisable to examine all the correspondence in the Ormsby collection. Note also that additional correspondence from specific individuals is contained in the author files subseries. All correspondence in either the author files or The Honest Ulsterman correspondence subseries is arranged chronologically. The restricted Seamus Heaney correspondence (1971-1996) is kept with personal literary correspondence (Subseries 1.1) because individual letters make mention not only of Honest Ulsterman submissions but Ormsby's other editorial and poetic projects.

The author files reflect Ormsby's own organizational system in which the editor maintained specific files of selected contributors to The Honest Ulsterman. In addition to correspondence, these files include an individual author's publication submissions of poetry and prose, as well as promotional and other printed material by and about the writer in question.

Another subseries includes work submitted to The Honest Ulsterman by authors not included in Ormsby's original author files. Unlike individual works that are catalogued by title in the author files, these poetry and prose submissions are collected by author. The titles of these submissions are not discretely listed. Two other subseries include materials related to the actual publication of specific volumes of The Honest Ulsterman and assorted printed material about the magazine.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p:
Organized into five subseries: (2.1) The Honest Ulsterman correspondence (2.2) The Honest Ulsterman author files (2.3) Submissions to
The Honest Ulsterman (2.4) Ulsterman Publications and (2.5) Printed material about The Honest Ulsterman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: All correspondence pertains to some aspect of Ormsby's involvement with The Honest Ulsterman. Many of the pieces are cover letters submitted with various poems or prose documents, though another large number of letters also deals with subscriptions to magazine. The earliest correspondence from 1967 to 1969 includes letters both to and from James Simmons, the founder and first editor of The Honest Ulsterman. Ormsby joined the operation as an editor in 1969.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged in chronological order. Undated correspondence is collected at the end of the subseries along with copies or drafts of letters sent by Ormsby.

did.unittitle: 1972-1975, The Honest Ulsterman correspondence from Ormsby

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: As editor of The Honest Ulsterman, Frank Ormsby kept detailed files on a host of individual authors. These files contain correspondence, often of both a personal and professional nature, sent to Ormsby or to the magazine. Also, many individual writers' manuscript or typescript submissions to the magazine have been preserved here. The author files include not just individual poems or prose pieces but larger sequences, collections, or pamphlets to be reviewed by the editor. Additional materials include interviews, worksheets from sessions of the Belfast Group, assorted promotional materials, and published reviews or essays about particular authors. Significantly, though these files originally served as the editor's record of contacts with a particular author, Ormsby maintained them even after leaving The Honest Ulsterman. This is especially true with the Seamus Heaney files that contain many reviews of Heaney's works published as late as 1995. The Heaney files are also notable for their collection of Heaney's published literary journalism from the late 1960's and early 1970's. Other substantial files pertain to Ciaran Carson, Gerald Dawe, Michael Foley, Robert Greacen, John Hewitt, Michael Longley, Derek Mahon, Medbh McGuckian, Paul Muldoon, Tom Paulin, Carol Rumens, and James Simmons.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Author files are arranged alphabetically by author. Correspondence is kept in one or more dated files. Individual works are preserved in discrete folders and listed in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of The Honest Ulsterman submissions from the late 1960's to the late 1980's by writers not included in Ormsby's author files. Materials in subsections related to poetry, prose, and artwork are arranged by author. These manuscript and typescript drafts do not include information about whether or not they were accepted for publication; nor do they include many editorial remarks by Ormsby.

did.unittitle: Weir, Anthony [poems and prints or related artwork]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials relevant to various projects or texts produced by Ulsterman Publications. As a small publishing operation in its own right, Ulsterman Publications produced The Honest Ulsterman as well as pamphlets or chapbooks for numerous younger poets. Subsections include typescripts and galley proofs of cover art for various pamphlets. Similarly, other subsections contain typescript mock-ups for two editions of The Honest Ulsterman and cover art for several other numbers of the magazine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series for writings by Ormsby includes manuscript and typescript drafts as well as galley proofs of writing in poetry or prose. The series also contains the scripts used in the broadcasts of various radio-plays, readings, and lectures. Additionally, all materials related to books Ormsby edited are located here. This series shows the development of individual works or volumes up to the point of publication. Published items are then arranged in the printed material series.

The poetry subseries (3.1) contains notes, manuscript, and typescript drafts of published and unpublished poems from 1970 to 1995. The published works are arranged chronologically according to major volume. Under each volume's heading, the poems are listed alphabetically. These folders include manuscript (MS) and/or typescript (TS) versions of the poems. Note that brackets often include other relevant information regarding variant titles, dates of creation, or relationships to other works. Many works are cross-referenced with others. Drafts of different poems are included in the same folder when there is no way of separating the poems. In this case, a poem's title might be listed without a box or folder number. A note in brackets will then refer the reader to the relevant folder where the document in question can be found. Typescripts and proofs of entire volumes are included at the end of each volume's subsection to roughly demonstrate the chronological development of a published volume.

Ormby's prose is collected in a distinct subseries (3.2) where works are then arranged by type. There are subsections for fiction, autobiographical prose, reviews, essays, speeches, and interviews. Notes after individual items indicate where and when the work was published if that information is available. Thus, many works are cross-referenced with the subseries for Ormsby's printed or published material. Because of the number of scripts and because Ormsby has been involved with broadcast presentations from 1970 to 1989, these are gathered in a separate subseries (3.3).

Materials in the subseries (3.4) pertaining to the anthologies edited by Ormbsy are arranged chronologically, like the poetry, by individual book. All items relating to the production of a specific text are presented in an order that gestures to the stages in the book's production. This subseries contains varied materials including research notes or lists of works under consideration for inclusion, actual manuscript or typescript submissions, photocopied published texts, as well as Ormsby's drafts of tables of contents, forewords, introductions, and indexes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: (3.1) Poetry by Frank Ormsby, (3.2) Prose by Frank Ormsby, (3.3) Scripts by Frank Ormsby, and (3.4) Works edited by Frank Ormsby.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries showcases Frank Ormsby's long and varied career as a poet. Notebooks from the early 1970's contain drafts of many of his earliest published poems as well as very interesting prose synopses or descriptions of other poems. Published poems are arranged chronologically by volume; poems in individual volumes are listed alphabetically. A separate subsection includes typescripts of volumes that were proposed for publication but ultimately went unpublished. A large number of unpublished poems are presented alphabetically. Many of these poems are dated by Ormsby. In some cases, notes indicate that particular texts are linked to others that are more readily dated. There are also a large number of untitled manuscript and typescript fragments roughly arranged chronologically by several-year periods.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three sections: (3.1a) Notebooks, (3.1b) Collected poetry, and (3.1c) Uncollected poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: As a prose writer, Ormsby produced works of fiction and autobiography, as well as book reviews, critical essays, speeches, and interviews. Notes describe specific documents with varying levels of detail, including date of composition and/or eventual publication. Many reviews and essays remain untitled, though most descriptions of such texts refer to the reviewed text or other salient details.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Ormsby's prose is collected in subsections pertaining to fiction, autobiography, book reviews, essays, speeches, and interviews. Individual texts are listed alphabetically by title under each subsection. Untitled reviews are listed alphabetically by the author under consideration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Across his career, Ormsby has been involved with literary programs written and presented for radio audiences. His various scripts are arranged chronologically by either the recording date or the transmission date. In some cases, Ormsby read parts himself. Most scripts were prepared for BBC Northern Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: In addition to his career as a poet, a writer of critical prose, and a magazine editor, Ormsby is noteworthy for his role in editing some very important anthologies or highly researched editions of single authors' works. Ormsby's Poets from the North of Ireland and A Rage for Order: Poetry of the Northern Ireland Troubles have proven to be both critically acclaimed and widely used poetry anthologies. His edition of the Belfast poet John Hewitt's Collected Poems has proven to be similarly valuable.

The correspondence related to the production of specific books is separately collected in the project correspondence subseries (1.2). Similarly, printed material (reviews and promotional materials) pertaining to specific volumes is arranged by book in the printed material subseries (5.2).

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Materials in this subseries are arranged chronologically by volume. Each book's subsection contains distinct items relevant to its production, though many of the books offer drafts of research material or bibliographies, introductions, and collections of primary, mostly photocopied documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The poetry and prose writing by others collected here represents unpublished material that has been sent personally to Ormsby. As editor of The Honest Ulsterman, most of the unpublished writing sent to him was submitted for publication, and all such manuscript and typescript drafts are kept in The Honest Ulsterman submissions subseries. Most of the items in the writings by others series are actually worksheets from sessions of the Belfast Group attended by Ormsby during the 1971-1972 academic year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Published material that has been collected by Ormsby is represented in this printed material series, which contains texts by Ormsby, texts about Ormsby's work, and texts by others about various issues of interest to Ormsby. In most cases, descriptions of individually catalogued items refer to the date and source of publication.

Published works by Ormsby are collected under one subseries divided into subsections for poetry and prose. These documents by Ormsby are arranged alphabetically. Printed material about Ormsby is gathered in a distinct subseries that is further divided into four subsections: one for articles, essays, or other biographical documents about Ormsby as a literary or public figure; one for reviews and clippings about Ormsby's books of poetry; another for reviews and clippings about the books that he has edited; and a fourth for promotional material for his work, including documents relating to readings and lectures.

Other printed material kept by Ormsby is collected in a third subseries that is also divided into various groups of related materials. This subseries collects a large number of poems, articles, reviews, essays, and stories written by many well-known writers and critics. Apart from the cut-outs, Ormsby also kept various magazines and newspapers in their entirety. An avid theater-goer, Ormsby preserved the playbills of numerous plays performed in Dublin and Belfast theaters from the early 1970's until the 1990's. Most of these programs, however, are from the 1970's. They are largely arranged by theater. Event programs and catalogues from artistic or literary occasions are arranged in yet another subsection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: (5.1) Printed material by Frank Ormsby, (5.2) Printed material about Frank Ormsby, and (5.3) Other printed material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Published texts by Ormsby are grouped as either poetry or prose in this subseries. In many cases, the poems have been simply cut out from newspapers or magazines. On occasion, the removal of individual pieces from the main body of a text has eliminated any record of the source or date of publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries organizes printed material about Ormsby in four separate subsections. The first subsection includes articles, essays, and biographical sketches about Ormsby as a poet and editor. The second subsection groups together numerous notices and reviews of Ormsby's poetry up to A Northern Spring (1986). These texts are arranged by the volume of poetry they consider. The next subsection collects the notices and reviews of the various books Ormsby has edited. A fourth subsection contains materials relevant to the promotion of Ormsby's poetry volumes and other books. This subsection includes many announcements and programs from Ormsby's own poetry readings, giving a sense his public literary life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The subseries for other printed material contains a wide assortment of texts grouped by type. The most prominent subsection is that dedicated to printed material by others. Ormsby has collected a large number of published poems, stories, reviews, and essays by an assortment of mostly Irish writers. These documents are arranged in alphabetical order by author. In some cases, Ormsby amassed multiple reviews of specific texts. These have been gathered together and listed as "assorted reviews" of a particular text. Furthermore, a number of folders contain miscellaneous, sometimes unattributed articles grouped together according to specific subjects or themes. Another subsection consists of various whole journals or magazines retained because of the literary or cultural relevance of particular articles. The printed material subseries also holds a substantial collection of theater and other event programs. The numerous playbills relating to specific theaters have been arranged according to theater. These offer a snapshot of the Dublin and Belfast theater scenes in the 1970's and 1980's. Other event programs are arranged in a more heterogeneous subsection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Frank Ormsby collection holds an assortment of photographs not only of Ormsby himself but of many of the major Irish and British writers of the late twentieth-century. Many of the photographs are head shots of high quality and were originally intended for promotional use by either the writer or the publishing house representing the writer. There are two subsections of photographs. One contains photos of Ormsby, and many of these are snapshots from readings or other literary events. The other subsection contains photographs of other literary figures. Folders dedicated to photographs of individual writers are arranged alphabetically by author. A photograph of a particular group of writers is organized separately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This small series contains various unclassifiable or disparate items. Some are of a personal nature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of unprocessed additions received in 2009, and includes writings by Ormsby, writings by others including Michael Longley and James Simmons, correspondence, and printed material. The writings include some of Ormsby’s first attempts at poetry, dating from 1958-1959, in addition his poetry notebooks from 1994-2004.
